p.content: The negative verbal elements, negative adverbs, negative indefinite pronouns and negation for nominal phrases will all be presented, then the type of negation system that
has will be determined.
In some languages verbal negation is an auxiliary element, while in others it is simply a verbal affix. English has both the negative auxiliary
, which is an independent word that must always follow another auxiliary, and the contraction form
, which is written as a suffix on the auxiliary. Examples of English negative transitive sentences include:
p.langData: The boy did not hit the ball
The boy didn’t hit the ball
p.content: and
p.langData: The boy might not have hit the ball

case.caseText: expresses verbal negation in the following ways.
does not have any way to express negation on either an auxiliary or the verb.

p.content: There are negative auxiliaries which are written as independent words. The negative auxiliary

case.caseText: may be the only auxiliary in the phrase.
may not be the only auxiliary in the phrase; the presence of a positive auxiliary is required.

p.content: There is
a negative affix which attaches to a positive auxiliary to make it negative. Examples of the negative auxiliary affixes attached to a positive auxiliary include:
There is
a negative affix that attaches to the verb to make it negative. Examples of the negative verbal affixes attached to a verb include:
There is
. Examples of these negative verbal elements are:

Examples of the negative auxiliary affixes attached to a positive auxiliary used in a complete sentence (without any negative arguments) include:

Full sentence examples with the other negative verbal elements allowed in
include:
As these examples show,

case.caseText: a negative auxiliary is not allowed without the verb also being negative.
the verb is not required to be negative when there is a negative auxiliary.

or
is expressed in

an independent negative word which occurs

a negative verbal affix, and a negative verb may occur with the positive locative adverbs to give a negative locative meaning. Examples of the positive locative adverbs with a negative verb are:

In

case.caseText: a negative adverb written as an independent word is not allowed without the verb or auxiliary also being negative.
a negative verb or auxiliary is not required when there is a negative adverb written as an independent word.

p.content: There are also negative versions of the indefinite pronouns, such as
and
. Note that these are formed from a negative and a generic noun or number. Sometimes these negative indefinites are not merged into a single word, as in
In
the negative indefinite pronouns

case.caseText: are all single-word pronouns.
are all nominal phrases instead of single-word pronouns.
are single-word pronouns, but others are nominal phrases.

p.content: These negative indefinite forms are:
Examples of the negative indefinite
used as the subject of a sentence are:
In

case.caseText: a negative subject is not allowed without the verb or auxiliary also being negative.
the verb or auxiliary is not required to be negative when the subject is negative.

p.content: The negatives meaning
or
can negate a nominal phrase. Note that
can occur in place of or before the other wide scope degree words or quantifiers, as in the English examples:
and
also occurs first in the nominal phrase, as shown in
and
. Negation of a nominal phrase normally occurs either first or last, so that it has the widest scope of all the modifiers of the noun in the phrase.
The negatives meaning
or
can negate a nominal phrase. Negation of a nominal phrase normally occurs either first or last, so that it has the widest scope of all the modifiers of the noun in the phrase.
There does not seem to be any way to negate a nominal phrase in
In
the elements that negate a nominal phrase

case.caseText: are all independent words.
are independent words, but some attach
attach

text.content: to the beginning of whatever word begins the nominal phrase as phrasal proclitics.
to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase as phrasal enclitics.
either to the beginning of whatever word begins the nominal phrase or to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase as phrasal clitics.
to the head noun in the nominal phrase as a prefix.
to the head noun in the nominal phrase as a suffix.
to the head noun in the nominal phrase, some as prefixes and some as suffixes.
either to the beginning or end of the nominal phrase as a phrasal clitic, or to the head noun in the nominal phrase as an affix.

are:

p.content: Negative nominal phrase examples without the positive wide scope quantifiers or degree elements are:
does not allow the negative elements to co-occur with the positive wide scope quantifiers or degree elements in a single nominal phrase.
allows the negative elements to co-occur with the positive wide scope quantifiers or degree elements in a single nominal phrase as shown here:
Any of these negative nominal phrases may be used as the subject of a full sentence. Some examples are:
As the above sentence examples show,

case.caseText: a negative subject is not allowed without also having a negative verb or auxiliary.
a negative verb or auxiliary is not required when the subject is negative.

p.content: Languages fall into two major classifications with respect to negation: Polarity Changing languages versus Negative Concord languages, exemplified by standard English versus Spanish or Black English, respectively.

Polarity Changing languages normally allow only a single negative element in the sentence for negation to be expressed (though technically any odd number of negatives expresses negative polarity) because the presence of two (or any even number of) negative elements changes the polarity back to positive. For example,
is negative, but
is positive because it means the same as
. The version with a negative auxiliary is expressed as
, using what is known as a ‘negative polarity item’ in object position. Such negative polarity items may occur as subjects in some contexts without any other negation present, such as
, but they may only occur in object position when some earlier element in the sentence is negative. For example, one can say
and
but without the negative subject or fronted negative adverb the negative auxiliary must be used, as in
and
p.langData: They will not find anyone anywhere

p.content: In Negative Concord languages, any number of negative elements expresses negative polarity, so in a Negative Concord version of English (such as Black English)

is the correct way to express a negative sentence with a negative object. In these languages, a negative element may normally occur in subject position or a fronted position without any other negative element present, but a negative object may only occur when some earlier element in the sentence is negative. Some Negative Concord languages have the stronger restriction that any negative word or phrase must co-occur with verbal negation and still others require fronting of the negative word or phrase, similarly to the fronting of question words or phrases in content questions.

The two major classifications with respect to negation are Polarity Changing languages versus Negative Concord languages. Polarity Changing languages normally allow only a single negative element in the sentence with special negative polarity items which appear in place of a second negative element. In contrast, any number of negative elements expresses negative polarity in Negative Concord languages, since the negative elements concord or agree in polarity.
is a

case.caseText: Polarity Changing
Negative Concord

p.content: language, since

case.caseText: the polarity changes between positive and negative with each instance of negation.
any number of negative elements simply agree in making the polarity negative.
has
does not have any

p.content: negative polarity items.

case.caseText: The following pronouns, determiners, and adverbs occur in object position or the normal adverb position instead of the equivalent negative element when another negative element is present in the sentence.
The negative pronouns, determiners, and adverbs may occur in object position or the normal adverb position even when there is another negative element in the sentence.

p.content: Examples with a positive subject and a negative
object nominal phrase include:
Examples with a positive subject and a negative
indirect object nominal phrase include:
As these examples show, a negative polarity item is
allowed to occur in object or indirect object position

case.caseText: unless the verb or auxiliary is negative.
unless either the verb or auxiliary or some other element in the sentence is negative.
without any restriction about other negative elements in the sentence.

p.content: As these examples show, a negative nominal phrase is
allowed to occur in object or indirect object position

case.caseText: unless the verb or auxiliary is negative.
unless either the verb or auxiliary or some other element in the sentence is negative.
without any restriction about other negative elements in the sentence.

p.content: As these examples show, a negative nominal phrase is
allowed to occur in object or indirect object position

case.caseText: unless the verb or auxiliary is negative.
unless either the verb or auxiliary or some other element in the sentence is negative.
without any restriction about other negative elements in the sentence.
A negative object must appear initially in the sentence, similarly to the fronting of interrogative phrases.
A negative object may appear initially in the sentence, or it may remain in its normal position.
A negative object may appear in the position directly before the verb, or it may remain in its normal position.
A negative object simply appears in its normal position in the sentence, without any movement.

p.content: Finally, examples with both a negative subject and a negative
object nominal phrase include:
Examples with both a negative subject and a negative
object nominal phrase are not allowed in
. Examples showing how these meanings are expressed using an indefinite or split into two sentences include:
Finally, examples with both a negative subject and a negative object nominal phrase include:
Examples with both a negative subject and a negative object nominal phrase are not allowed in
. Examples showing how these meanings are expressed using an indefinite or split into two sentences include:

text.content: If both the subject and object are negative,

case.caseText: both negative elements must appear initially in the sentence.
both negative elements may appear initially in the sentence, or the negative object may remain in its normal position.
both negative elements may appear in the position directly before the verb, or the negative object may remain in its normal position.
only the negative subject is fronted, and the negative object simply appears in its normal position in the sentence.
